Helder Hugo dos Santos

  • Endereço para acessar este CV: http://lattes.cnpq.br/0503772383273150
  • Última atualização do currículo em 09/09/2019

Helder is a Ph.D. candidate and fellow of the International Max Planck Research School for Organismal Biology (Konstanz, Germany). Currently, he has affiliation with (i) the Department of Collective Behaviour at the Max Planck Institute of Animal Behavior, (ii) the Department of Biology of University of Konstanz and (iii) the Centre for the Advanced Study of Collective Behaviour (Konstanz, Germany). His current research focuses on understanding underlying mechanisms of collective animal behaviour and is developed in collaboration with the Department of Entomology at the Federal University of Viçosa (Brazil). In 2016, he was awarded a full scholarship by the German Academic Exchange Service (in German: Deutscher Akademischer Austauschdienst, DAAD) to develop his doctoral studies in Germany. His background includes a MSc. degree in Entomology (Federal University of Viçosa, Brazil, 2016), a BSc. & Licentiate degree in Biological Sciences (Pontifical Catholic University of Minas Gerais, Brazil, 2009) and a Technical degree in Electromechanics (Federal Center of Technological Education of Minas Gerais, 2004). (Texto informado pelo autor)

Consultor Agrícola (Agricultural Consultant): Monitoramento de pragas e doenças em culturas agrícolas da costa leste da Florida (tomate, milho, feijão-verde, alface, etc.). Emissão de relatórios técnicos sobre o nível de pragas, doenças e plantas daninhas. Execução de ensaios para testes de químicos agrícolas em fazenda experimental. Amostragem e identificação de espécies de pragas em laboratório. Trabalho nas fazendas desenvolvido em parte de forma independente. Auxílio no treinamento de novos trainees.

International Max Planck Research School for Organismal Biology, IMPRS, Alemanha.
Vínculo institucional

2016 - Atual
Vínculo: Fellow, Enquadramento Funcional: PhD candidate, Regime: Dedicação exclusiva.
Outras informações
The International Max Planck Research School (IMPRS) for Organismal Biology is a close cooperation between the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology and the Department of Biology at the University of Konstanz. Its aim is to provide first-class training and education for outstanding doctoral students from all over the world in a stimulating research environment. This competitive doctoral program provides its fellows with an excellent starting platform for a successful career in the fields of animal behaviour, ecology, evolution, physiology, and neurobiology. Our faculty is comprised of more than 30 leading researchers from the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology and the Department of Biology at the University of Konstanz; our PhD fellows come from 37 different countries. Besides their own research, the IMPRS fellows attend laboratory courses and workshops in relevant transferable skills like scientific writing and project management. Talks by invited speakers during our annual IMPRS symposium, student retreats, and conference participations complete the individually tailored curriculum. Program details can be found here. In general, the PhD should be completed within three years. The official teaching language is English. German language classes are offered to students from abroad.

Atividades

Pesquisa e desenvolvimento , Department of Collective Behaviour, Max Planck Institute for Ornithology, .

Projetos de pesquisa
2014 - Atual
Cohabitation among termite species: how to reduce eventual conflicts inside the nest?
Descrição: An intriguing scenario emerges from the combination of two isolated facts about the behavior of termite species. Firstly, when meeting individuals from a different colony, termites typically exhibit aggressive behaviour. Secondly, different termite species often establish long-term cohabitation in a single nest, a closed environment with high chances for inter-specific encounters and low probability of evasion. In other words, despite the natural trend for aggressiveness, different termite species are capable to cohabiting in a single nest. The question that raises is: why is that even possible? In this project, we explore allospecific termite-termite cohabitation, focusing on the behaviors cohabitants exhibit at individual level, in order to test the hypothesis that, once inevitably exposed to their host, inquiline termite individuals would tend to adopt passive behaviors, preventing confront escalation..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (1) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Helder Hugo dos Santos - Coordenador / Paulo Fellipe Cristaldo - Integrante / Og DeSouza - Integrante.
2014 - Atual
Cohabitation among termite species: how to reduce eventual conflicts inside the nest?
Descrição: An intriguing scenario emerges from the combination of two isolated facts about the behavior of termite species. Firstly, when meeting individuals from a different colony, termites typically exhibit aggressive behaviour. Secondly, different termite species often establish long-term cohabitation in a single nest, a closed environment with high chances for inter-specific encounters and low probability of evasion. In other words, despite the natural trend for aggressiveness, different termite species are capable to cohabiting in a single nest. The question that raises is: why is that even possible? In this project, we explore allospecific termite-termite cohabitation, focusing on the behaviors cohabitants exhibit at individual level, in order to test the hypothesis that, once inevitably exposed to their host, inquiline termite individuals would tend to adopt passive behaviors, preventing confront escalation..
Situação: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.
Alunos envolvidos: Graduação: (0) / Especialização: (0) / Mestrado acadêmico: (1) / Mestrado profissional: (0) / Doutorado: (0) .

Integrantes: Helder Hugo dos Santos - Coordenador / Paulo Fellipe Cristaldo - Integrante / Og DeSouza - Integrante.

Outras informações relevantes

 
The International Max Planck Research School (IMPRS) for Organismal Biology is a close cooperation between the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology and the Department of Biology at the University of Konstanz. Its aim is to provide first-class training and education for outstanding doctoral students from all over the world in a stimulating research environment. This competitive doctoral program provides its fellows with an excellent starting platform for a successful career in the fields of animal behaviour, ecology, evolution, physiology, and neurobiology.
